title: [NSFW] Dificuldade em reproduzir vídeos 1080p ou 1080p60 H264 codec
content:
Meu Firefox não está conseguindo reproduzir vídeos em 1080p de 30 (ou 29,97) ou 60 FPS, a imagem fica travando, mas o áudio está normal. Se for um vídeo em 720p60, por exemplo, o navegador consegue reproduzir as imagens e o áudio suavemente. Se eu tentar reproduzir esses vídeos no Google Chrome ou baixar eles e usar no Media Player Classic (MPC-HC), eles conseguem reproduzir vídeos em 1080p sem problemas. Em todos os casos, são vídeos com codec H264.

Um detalhe, o Firefox aparenta reproduzir vídeos em 1080p de 24 FPS, mas seu ficar mexendo no mouse sob a página, ou no próprio vídeo, a imagem fica travando até que eu pare de mexer no mouse.

Eu tentei pesquisar por soluções (a maioria pelo reddit do Firefox), mas não consegui resolver o meu problema. Alguns sugeriram modificações no about:config para mexer nessas coisas: layers.acceleration.force-enabled gfx.direct3d11.use-double-buffering media.gpu-process-decoder layers.gpu-process.enabled

Em todos os casos, fiz a modificação (uma por vez) e testava no vídeo, se não desse certo, voltava para a configuração padrão de antes.

Tentei seguir um troubleshooting básico do reddit do Firefox, envolvendo limpar cache, desativar as extensões, atualizar o drive gráfico, manter as configurações de desempenho ativadas nos "settings". Nenhum resolveu. Tentei criar um novo "profile" do zero, nada instalado ou registrado, apenas copiei e colei uma página contendo um vídeo em 1080p60 para reproduzir e a imagem ficou travando, só o áudio estava normal.

Muitas pessoas mencionaram o YouTube, eu também testei um vídeo de 1080p60 e o problema persiste, só que eu posso baixar a resolução para 720p60 e ele funciona de boas. Mas em sites fora do Youtube, o vídeo só fica disponível em 1080p60, por exemplo, o que torna a situação um incômodo. Outros mencionaram a questão do codec vp9, por isso eu também deixo claro que até vídeos em H264 o Firefox não está conseguindo reproduzir direito, enquanto que o Chrome e MPC-HC funcionam de boas.

Usando um laptop com CPU: AMD A4-3310MX APU GPU (integrada): AMD Radeon HD 6480G RAM: 4GB OS: Windows 7 Professional SP1 (64 bits) Firefox 113.0.1 MPC-HC (Nightly, 2.0.0.5) Chrome 109.0.5414.120

No espaço de "Informações técnicas", tentei colocar informações relacionadas a aba "about:support", outra sugestão que deram quando fosse entrar em contato com o suporte.

Para finalizar, os vídeos que eu fico mencionando envolvem conteúdo explícito, preferi não postar aqui, mas se precisarem de mais informações ou links para testar, já aviso de antemão sobre assunto.
creator: lucas234

title: Sync server not reacheable
content:
I'm having problems to sync my account with one computer, and apparently the reason is that it cannot reach the sync server

https://sync-1-us-west1-g.sync.services.mozilla.com

I can open the above url from my phone and from one laptop, but I cannot open that address from the laptop that I'm trying to synchronize. I got the address from the sync-log

Sync.Resource WARN GET request to https://sync-1-us-west1-g.sync.services.mozilla.com/1.5/161701144/info/collections failed: [Exception... "The connection has timed out" nsresult: "0x804b000e (NS_ERROR_NET_TIMEOUT)" location: "<unknown>" data: no] No traceback available

Sync.Service DEBUG verifyLogin failed: [Exception... "The connection has timed out" nsresult: "0x804b000e (NS_ERROR_NET_TIMEOUT)" location: "<unknown>" data: no] No traceback available

Both computers and phone are connected to the same local network.

title: Weird Grey Rectangle Overlaping Bookmarks Section (Sideberry + VerticalFox)
content:
I am trying get the Edge vertical tabs on Firefox (Windows 11), using the Sideberry addon with VerticalFox tweaks put in place.

It works almost perfect, but i have encountered this weird grey rectangle that overlaps a section of my bookmarks above the Sideberry sidebar (as shown in the image).

I believe that this rectangle appeared at the moment i have set the native tabs to hidden. It also shows the same context menu as most other windows apps.

I have tried the fix from here, no luck with that.

Does anyone know how i could make this disappear, or at least make it the same color as my bookmarks section?

Could this be related to themes? I am using the native Firefox dark theme and tried a few else, the rectangle changed it's color slightly when i did that, but it never disappeared.

PS: The gap on the left side of my bookmarks is put there on purpose. When i remove it, the rectangle overlaps my first two bookmarks with full opacity and it becomes impossible to click on them.

PPS: I have found out that i have been using a wrong version of Sidebery (5.0). Fixed that, but the rectangle remains.

title: Workaround to increase display space of URL in the address bar
content:
The display space for the URL in the Address Bar had shrunk so much I couldn't discern the URL of the webpage I was on, and I couldn't see the Search input string. If the windows exceeded the display area's tipping point, it went from unusably short to not visible.

I couldn't find info on how to flex the space, so I moved a bunch of icons to the Bookmarks Toolbar. The URL now has much more display space, which restores its usability to smaller window sizes — to a point.

So, I had to sacrifice display space for the bookmarks on the Bookmarks Toolbar. Have I overlooked a method to avoid this trade-off while still achieving my goal?

title: How to disable search suggestion in address bar in case of 404 errors?
content:
I'm a software developer working on some web application and sometimes need to manually add URL components in the address bar of an open tab simpyl to test something. For example I have some tab open shwoing the web page under "http://localhost:8080/entry" and I need to test "http://localhost:8080/entry/foobar" by manually adding "/foobar" to the URL. Depending on if "/foobar" exists or not, either some web page is shown or inc ase of a HTTP status code 404 Firefox automatically opens a new tab and forwards my input as search to Google.

That is not what I want. I want Firefox to simply show the HTTP status code 404 like the other browsers I use. Though, I want to be able to search in the address bar in general, only not in case there's an existing working URL open already and I change the child path only.

Is there some way to disable the behaviour of Firefox for 404s or do I need to completely disable searches in the address bar instead?

Thanks!
creator: thorsten.schoening

title: Firefox restores previous Session every time after reboot
content:
Usually I don't properly close my applications before rebooting or shutting down my machine. Firefox then restores my previous session, which I don't want.

I've tried the following but this didn't work:

  • Verify "Open previous windows and tabs" isn't checked
  • set `browser.sessionstore.max_resumed_crashes` to 0
  • set `browser.sessionstore.resume_from_crash` to false

Do you have any idea, why this doesn't work? or any other ideas how I could disable this?

title: How to tell when Firefox profile initialization complete from command line
content:
When a new profile is created from the command line with `firefox -CreateProfile <name>` Firefox creates a profile directory containing a single file named "times.json". The profile directory is initialized (with 70 or so more files, 16MB or so in total) when Firefox opens the profile for the first time - in my use-case by doing `firefox -P <name>`. I see that this process spawns several sub processes and would like to know which one is responsible for generating the profile files/directories so I can detect when it has completed.

Alternatively - can you point me at the source code responsible so I can figure it out from there. If, for example, there is a manifest of profile files/directories to be created I could perhaps use that to verify when the initialization process is complete.

My system is Linux, but I am looking for solution that works on any platform.

Many thanks.

title: Privacy/Incognito cookies shared with non private window
content:
So I'm running a Firefox Developer Edition (I do this to have my work related stuff separated from my personal stuff).

I was testing A/B testing software on our website, when I noticed that Private window shared some of the non-Private window cookies.

I have made a recording of the issue in action. On the left side is a private mode window (notice the missing extensions), on the right side is a normal window. They are both open on the same page and first thing to notice, is when I refresh the private window, cookies in inspector "flash" in both windows, indicating that there are changes. After that, I'm interested in two cookies: "gbuuid" and "growthBookVariants", it seems like they are shared and when I refresh one windows, it's value is "synced" to the second window.

Now this is annoying, as I have to clear those cookies to test if I get a different variant. When a colleague tested it on Windows, it didn't happen so maybe it's something with my settings/extensions? I attached my privacy settings, but when I fiddled with those, nothing seemed to change.

Eddig nem találtam olyan opciót, hogy mondjuk lementhessem a Firefox állapotát, mert ha rákeresek, akkor is a szinkronizálást ajánlgatja.
